So, uh, they removed the weather system and there is no natural day/night cycle. 

Fun game, but whyyyyyyy remove such little things that create immersion?

This is a game I keep coming back to when I want something nice, cute and relaxing. I like designing a nice looking but efficient settlement, honing my city layout strategies, building monuments, decorating, and sometimes just watching my inhabitants go sit on a bench. 

I also like that there aren't (and won't be) any enemies or wild animals attacking my settlement. All combat happens off the map, is completely optional and initiated by the player. Just train and equip your troops, send them off and hope they come back mostly in one piece and with nice loot. Or ignore combat alltogether and build a peaceful settlement focused on production and trade. 

There are still some things that need polishing for the perfect medieval city builder experience, but no more than other city builders I've played. I'm looking forward to the next update which promises to do some of those polishes, but the game is fully enjoyable as it is.

Honestly quite chill, hope they keep adding stuff like snow or different biomes.
It has a nice charm to it and could probably use more QOL stuff but overall a nice 7,5 game.

I am very disappointed!

I decided to buy this game because I like such kind of games.
Because I wanted to play it directly I violated my personal rule to buy games only during special sale periods. So I paid full price (34€).

The game itself is very nice and I love it but its unplayable for me at the moment.
I started my session and everything went smooth and without any issues for 3h. 
When I started the game again on the next day, it started on my second screen for what ever reason. I had to correct that via setup but after that the game keeps crashing to the desktop after 5 to 10 minutes after every start!

I tried to start as admin, I deleted the config folder to re-initialize the files there. I stored saves in the cloud and denied that as well. 
The game keeps crashing!

That is very disappointing! This seems to be a known problem since the game was released, so why was that not fixed?

I really want to play the game and to support the developer with a positive feedback or recommandation. 
So fix it!


===== EDIT =====
I found some information how to get a more stable game experience. So I tried some of these things.

What seams to help so far:

- Set the FPS limit ingame to the value which corresponds to the value of your monitor. To be on the save side I also disconnected my second monitor.

- I installed Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable

- Furthermore I added some starting boundaries via Steam to force the game to start with DirectX11 -> -force-d3d11


Maybe that is helpful for somebody. For me it worked so far. Now the game does not crash every 10 minutes as before. But sometimes there are still crashes to desktop but on the other hand I can play 2 hours without a crash also. 

So in this case I will change my negative feedback to a positive, but with a huge qotationmark! 
The game itself is fantastic and recommandable in total, but be aware of this massive issue regarding Crash-To-Desktop which is very frustrating!

The organic nature of buildings sprawling and upgrading is unique and makes for pleasantly chaotic town layouts over the typical grid-based building of other games. Well worth it for town-builder novices and veterans alike!

This completely redefined the genre for me, and is already "inspiring" other games to go down a similar path.

Hogs quite a few system resources, and while it looks like a laid-back, cozy decoration sim, the economic side can get a little brutal as you spread your settlements across the maps, so keep that in mind.

In short- it is a good and satisfying city-builder game. I like the visuals and the core gimmick of no grids is really cool. I also like the trading mechanics and how they interact with other systems in the game. It's great that they have several modes of play - default is great for learning the game, challenge rules are a nice way to push experienced players to explore game in more detail especially when combined with aspirations, and there is a casual mode for those that just want to build a pretty city without stress. So - something for everyone. 

I also have some complaints - from time to time a weird bug would pop up. And for veterans of city builders there is some frustration from opaque systems on how many resources are produced and how many are consumed by various buildings or over time. If you're one of those people that likes to optimise perfectly, it's kind of not possible. The overproduction is the way to go if possible, or topping up through trade and selling off surpluses when they happen. 
Logistics are also a bit basic and can lead to frustrations on challenge difficulty. 
And finally not being able to micromanage where the villagers live directly. There are some workarounds, but when I tried them I had to deal with glitches in the game, where a citizen would leave the house, the house would start downgrading, even though I promoted two other villagers to citizen status. Then you pay the cost of downgrading the building, and when it's finished the game recognizes that there are indeed two citizens in the building , so it starts upgrading again, with you paying the costs of it again. 

Overall, though, I still enjoy very much it and would recommend it. Just be aware that it's not perfect

entire village for resources that are found nearby.

*Placement of bridges (for construction) is a bit tricky due to that if not "perfectly" alined
villagers won't use it. Sometimes it needs to be adjusted several times before villagers being happy.
*One cannot manually assign monks/non to monestary workplaces as the game automatically assign monks/nuns to tasks ( i think in chronological order of sub-buidling construction

Overall this a really good game and the cons are more of he nusiance type and really game breaking.

If you're at all a fan of city builders, this is certainly one that should not be missed, especially if you are fond of the medieval theme! One thing that turns me away from many other games in this genre is that they tend to stick to a grid system, making the final city feel inorganic and lack a certain sense of immersion that I'm after. And on the contrary, games like Cities Skylines allow you to build in a more free-flowing way if you want, but I tend to feel overwhelmed at just how much there is to focus on in that game. Foundation, to me, is the perfect middle ground; everything feels organic without needing extraordinary efforts. Supply lines are simple and easy to follow, and it really doesn't feel like I have to micromanage in order to build a successful community. There are multiple paths your city can take as it grows, and you're only really limited by your own constraints. Above all else, I believe that the monument building feature in Foundation is second to none, allowing you to really let your creativity go wild and build some truly unique structures. I can't recommend this game enough, and I'm sure it will only get better as the devs continue to polish it!

There’s a certain magic to this game that keeps pulling me back in. Whenever I’m craving something calm and cozy, it’s the first title I launch. Designing a settlement here feels less like managing a city and more like nurturing a living, breathing world. I love shaping the terrain, arranging buildings just so, optimizing production flows, and watching my little medieval town blossom into a bustling community. Half the fun is simply observing the villagers go about their day, resting on benches, chatting by the market stalls, or wandering through the paths I’ve carefully planned.

What really sets this game apart is the complete lack of pressure from enemies or random disasters. Nothing storms the gates or sabotages your progress. Any combat that does exist is entirely player-driven and takes place far from your town. If you want to train an army and send them out on risky expeditions for treasure, you can. If you'd rather ignore fighting altogether and focus on crafting, trading, and city design, that’s perfectly viable too.

While it still has room for refinement, it’s already a wonderfully polished and genuinely relaxing city builder. And with new updates on the horizon promising even more improvements, I’m excited to see how the experience evolves. For now, it’s a delightfully peaceful escape, one I keep finding new reasons to return to.

Pretty much everything you could wish for in a relaxing city-building game. Unique way of extremely natural town building paired with pretty good customization options for building larger projects. This game is definitely NOT a survival city-builder a lot of people expect when they first try it, but it never was meant to be a game like that. Say goodbye to overoptimalized building, min-maxing efficiency of pathfinding or geometrical symetry of everything. Just relax and watch your town grown in organic manner no other game can currently offer.

You could say that this game fills a huge void created by a long gone Settlers and a very disappointing simulation (if you can even call it that) in the Anno series of games. But that wouldn't do it justice to this gem of a game. 

Every little royal subject of your kingdom has its own identity, very well defined. They go to work, come home, shop, goes for a beer, etc. Visitors can also come to enjoy your town while sleeping at the inn. Based on their status,  they all have different needs however as opposed to Anno, the entire industry chain is fully simulated. The baker isn't just gonna want flour, but that bag of flour needs to be carried from the windmill, and you'll see in real time a person doing just that.

But the game goes way beyond simulating needs and industry chains. You can customize and upgrade parts of every building, some people will have requirements that will require beautification, safety, entertainment, etc. There are so many mechanisms and content in this game it'll make your head spin. Honestly, this game has the potential to be really, really good; but, has a lot of issues with almost every aspect of it. 

The biggest problem all stems from a lack of explanation about why or when anything happens. You're expected to constantly manage incoming and outgoing money; but, it's not just "this building costs 2 gold per month" it's "this building costs 2 gold per month, and then maybe more depending on some abstract variables that we will not tell you about nor will we explain them when the costs goes up unexpectedly."

The tutorial is horrible. Any "advice" you can get will lead you towards bankruptcy immediately. "Set up trade for tools" -> run out of money within a couple months. "Make bread" -> you'll need way too much space to do that at the point they tell you. "Levy from your citizens" -> everyone hates you now.

The AI pathing is neat at first. Your villagers will create pathways as they walk to work, meaning the roads develop dynamically. However, since they are set to find the most efficient path to where they want to go, you'll have villagers walking through each others front yards, rather than using the obvious straight road that goes right down the centre of your village. You can fix that by putting up fences; but, this all comes back to money. Even trying to decorate costs you a ton of money that you don't have.

I'm aware some people have put in hundreds of hours, or watched walkthroughs on how to play. In my opinion, you shouldn't have to. The game doesn't need to hold your hand; but, it hides too much information from the player and blindsides them later.  

Onto the good: There are a lot of different buildings and everything is pretty. The tech tree is long and things are thrown at you slowly, so you won't get overwhelmed as to what you can build next (the order of when or why you should is a different story.) Lots of customisation options; you can rename anything, place things wherever you want, and some buildings are pieced together instead of being just placed as one building.

If you like micromanaging and calculating income, this game is probably for you!
If you're like me, and want to make a cute village and see it flourish into a beautiful city, stay away.

(Note: there is a creative mode; but, that of course takes the fun out of watching the village grow as you play.)

A Foundation with a Crumbling Base...

We’re in a genre where, honestly, it feels like we’ve seen just about everything—especially when it comes to pure city-building.
Game series like Anno, The Settlers, Age of Empires, SimCity, and many more offer a much wider variety of mechanics and personalities to play around with.

In Foundation, I personally miss the core that makes a game truly enjoyable in the long run.
Maybe it’s the familiar elements we’ve all seen a hundred times before, the bland characters, or the meaningless mechanics - like the military system. Why even have one if there’s no one to fight?

If I had to compare Foundation to anything, it would be The Settlers III.
Similar NPC route planning, no unnecessary mechanics, way more bustle and charm, NPCs that actually feel lively, a functioning military, and a wide variety of missions and factions...
Even though the graphics can’t compete anymore (the game released back in 2000), the fun factor easily holds up. And if you sprinkle in just a dash of Anno for the city-building aspect, it makes it really hard for me to recommend Foundation.

Especially at a price still above €20 - even on sale.

Honestly, this game has the potential to be really, really good; but, has a lot of issues with almost every aspect of it. 

The biggest problem all stems from a lack of explanation about why or when anything happens. You're expected to constantly manage incoming and outgoing money; but, it's not just "this building costs 2 gold per month" it's "this building costs 2 gold per month, and then maybe more depending on some abstract variables that we will not tell you about nor will we explain them when the costs goes up unexpectedly."

The tutorial is horrible. Any "advice" you can get will lead you towards bankruptcy immediately. "Set up trade for tools" -> run out of money within a couple months. "Make bread" -> you'll need way too much space to do that at the point they tell you. "Levy from your citizens" -> everyone hates you now.

The AI pathing is neat at first. Your villagers will create pathways as they walk to work, meaning the roads develop dynamically. However, since they are set to find the most efficient path to where they want to go, you'll have villagers walking through each others front yards, rather than using the obvious straight road that goes right down the centre of your village. You can fix that by putting up fences; but, this all comes back to money. Even trying to decorate costs you a ton of money that you don't have.

I'm aware some people have put in hundreds of hours, or watched walkthroughs on how to play. In my opinion, you shouldn't have to. The game doesn't need to hold your hand; but, it hides too much information from the player and blindsides them later.  

Onto the good: There are a lot of different buildings and everything is pretty. The tech tree is long and things are thrown at you slowly, so you won't get overwhelmed as to what you can build next (the order of when or why you should is a different story.) Lots of customisation options; you can rename anything, place things wherever you want, and some buildings are pieced together instead of being just placed as one building.

If you like micromanaging and calculating income, this game is probably for you!
If you're like me, and want to make a cute village and see it flourish into a beautiful city, stay away.

(Note: there is a creative mode; but, that of course takes the fun out of watching the village grow as you play.)

At the moment: Don't recommend. But I will keep an eye on it.

A Foundation with a Crumbling Base...

We’re in a genre where, honestly, it feels like we’ve seen just about everything—especially when it comes to pure city-building.
Game series like Anno, The Settlers, Age of Empires, SimCity, and many more offer a much wider variety of mechanics and personalities to play around with.

In Foundation, I personally miss the core that makes a game truly enjoyable in the long run.
Maybe it’s the familiar elements we’ve all seen a hundred times before, the bland characters, or the meaningless mechanics - like the military system. Why even have one if there’s no one to fight?

If I had to compare Foundation to anything, it would be The Settlers III.
Similar NPC route planning, no unnecessary mechanics, way more bustle and charm, NPCs that actually feel lively, a functioning military, and a wide variety of missions and factions...
Even though the graphics can’t compete anymore (the game released back in 2000), the fun factor easily holds up. And if you sprinkle in just a dash of Anno for the city-building aspect, it makes it really hard for me to recommend Foundation.

Especially at a price still above €20 - even on sale.
